title: Saedinenie Snowfield
text:
Saedinenie Snowfield (, ) on <a href="Livingston%20Island">Livingston Island</a> in the <a href="South%20Shetland%20Islands">South Shetland Islands</a>, <a href="Antarctica">Antarctica</a> is situated southwest of <a href="Rose%20Valley%20Glacier">Rose Valley Glacier</a>, west of <a href="Panega%20Glacier">Panega Glacier</a>, northwest of <a href="Kaliakra%20Glacier">Kaliakra Glacier</a>, north of lower <a href="Perunika%20Glacier">Perunika Glacier</a> and east-northeast of <a href="Tundzha%20Glacier">Tundzha Glacier</a>. It is bounded by <a href="Teres%20Ridge">Teres Ridge</a> to the west, the glacial divide between the <a href="Drake%20Passage">Drake Passage</a> and <a href="Bransfield%20Strait">Bransfield Strait</a> to the south, <a href="Gleaner%20Heights">Gleaner Heights</a>, <a href="Elhovo%20Gap">Elhovo Gap</a> and <a href="Leslie%20Hill%2C%20Livingston%20Island">Leslie Hill</a> to the southeast, and <a href="Leslie%20Gap">Leslie Gap</a> and <a href="Vidin%20Heights">Vidin Heights</a> to the east. The snowfield extends 4.7 km inland and 15.5 km in southwest-northeast direction, and drains into <a href="Hero%20Bay">Hero Bay</a> between <a href="Melta%20Point">Melta Point</a> and <a href="Slab%20Point">Slab Point</a>.
A survey bivouac in eastern Saedinenie Snowfield near <a href="Leslie%20Hill%2C%20Livingston%20Island">Leslie Hill</a> was occupied 24–28 December 2004.
The feature was named after the <a href="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>n town of <a href="Saedinenie%2C%20Plovdiv%20Province">Saedinenie</a> ('Reunification'), in association with the 120th anniversary of the <a href="Unification%20of%20Bulgaria">Reunification</a> of the <a href="Principality%20of%20Bulgaria">Principality of Bulgaria</a> and the province of <a href="Eastern%20Rumelia">Eastern Rumelia</a> in 1885. This is one of the Bulgarian <a href="toponyms">names</a> bestowed on hitherto nameless geographical features by the <a href="Tangra%202004/05">Tangra 2004/05</a> Expedition.
Location.
The snowfield is centred at (Bulgarian topographic survey <a href="Tangra%202004/05">Tangra 2004/05</a> and mapping in 2005 and 2009).
